item.title: Class presentation
item.description: Your research presentation should not be a simple “replay” of your topic but should be re-designed so that you spend some time talking spontaneously employ more than one medium (such as slides) engage your classmates in discussion A successful presentation will focus on one part of the research, without trying to cover all of the research in your paper. You will have about 15–20 minutes to make your presentation; this will include time devoted to questions and answers.

item.title: Course Calendar
item.description: Meeting Topic Discuss Lecture Reading Assignment(s) due 1⁄7 (M) Introduction to ANTH 464 1⁄9 (W) What is Hawaiian archaeology? Questions 1 What is Archaeology? 1⁄11 (F) History of archaeological research Questions 1 Chapter 1 1⁄14 (M) Environmental setting Questions 2 Chapter 2 1⁄16 (W) The anthropological project Questions 2 Encountering Old Hawai`i 1⁄18 (F) Gift economy and property Questions 2 1⁄21 (M) Holiday: Martin Luther King, Jr.

item.title: Discussion Questions
item.description: These discussion questions help guide the conversation. They are meant to augment the questions you bring to class. Also, note that Discussion Questions 1–6 include the three questions that will appear on the mid-term examination. Discussion Questions 1 How has the institutional framework of Hawaiian archaeology changed over time? What was the innovation introduced by the settlement pattern approach? What research questions occupy Hawaiian archaeologists today? How is archaeology different from history?

item.title: Term Paper Instructions
item.description: Term Paper Schedule Date Assignment 2⁄1 (F) Choose excavation report 2⁄8 (F) Reconstitution 2⁄15 (F) Acquisition 1 3⁄1 (F) Acquisition 2 3⁄8 (F) Specific Topic 3⁄15 (F) Structuration 3⁄29 (F) Abstract, Outline, Bibliography 4⁄5 (F) First draft 4⁄15, 17, 29 or 5⁄1 5⁄10 (F) Final term paper Choose excavation report Identify the report you’ve chosen from the following list.

item.title: Spring 2019 Syllabus for Hawaiian Archaeology ANTH 464
item.description: Meeting Times MWF 9:30–10:20 Classroom SAUNDERS 345 Instructor Dr. Thomas S. Dye (tdye@hawaii.edu) Office: Saunders 346B Office Hour: F 10:30–11:30 (or by appointment) Course Description This course is designed to provide undergraduate (and graduate) students an in-depth introduction to the archaeology of the Hawaiian Islands. Topics that we will consider include (but not be limited to) archaeology’s contribution to traditional and post-Contact history, the geographical and historical origins of the Polynesian discoverers, the timing of island colonization and settlement, the development and innovation of food production and craft economies, the emergence of socio-political hierarchies, and some consequences of contact and colonialism.
